module.p: a-mach [to] outside is an elative adverb of motion along a trajectory (contrasting with both the adessive? a-muigh [at] outside and the illative a-steach [to] inside).

Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. [...]
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a rug out of the car for sitting on. [...] td. 6
examples from Gairm –
Bha i ceud bliadhna a dh’ aois is esan dhà air fhichead. Cha robh e ach mìos no dhà a-mach ás an oilthigh. Bha a nighean a’ fuireachd còmhla rithe. Bha ise ceithir fichead. Shaoil e gu robh a’ chailleach ann an dòigh na bu shunndaiche na a nighean. [...]
She was a hundred years old and him twenty two. He was just a month or two out of the university. Her daughter was living with her. She was eighty. He thought that the old woman was in a way livelier than her daughter. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn cf. à out of
biblical examples –
A Nis is iad so ainmeanna chloinn Israeil, a thàinig do’n Eiphit; thàinig gach duine agus a theaghlach maille re Iacob: Reuben, Simeon, Lebhi, agus Iudah, [...] Agus na h-anman uile a thàinig a mach a leasraidh Iacoib, bu deich agus tri fichead anam iad; oir bha Ioseph ’san Eiphit a cheana. [...]
Now these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob. Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah, [...] And all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were seventy souls: for Joseph was in Egypt already. [KJV] Ecsodus I.1–5

rach a-mach go out(side) –
pedagogical examples –
Chan eil iad a’ dol a-mach. | Tha Màiri a’ dol a-mach. | Chaidh Iain a-mach. Cha deach Uilleam a-mach. | a’ chaileag a chaidh a-mach | a’ chaileag nach deach a-mach | Tha/bha/bidh/bhiodh iad air a dhol a-mach. | Cha toireadh màthair Dhòmhnaill cead dha a dhol a-mach. | Nach àbhaist dhi a bhith a’ dol a-mach feasgar?
They are not going out. | Mary is going out. | John went out. | William did not go out. | the girl who went out | the girl who did not go out | They (will/would) have/had gone out. | Donald’s mother would not give him permission to go out. | Doesn’t she usually go out in the evening? td. 22, 31, 38, 121, 124, 158–9, 169 [199], 170

Note the idiom rach a-mach air ... quarrel with, fall out with –
pedagogical examples –
Bha Anna a’ teabachadh/teabachdainn a dhol a-mach air.
Ann was on the verge of falling out with him. td. 177
Chaidh e a-mach air luchd an airm.
He quarrelled with the army people. td. 478

thig a-mach come out(side) –
pedagogical examples –
A bheil sibh a’ tighinn a-mach?
Are you coming out? td. 195
Bha e a’ tighinn a-mach às an taigh.
He was coming out of the house. td. 49
